title: How are dictators different from facilitators in terms of decision making? - Quora

response.answer_text: The dictator gets to say: “I don’t care what you think: do it my way” and be obeyed. Well, that or or overthrown. The term dictator originally meant an emergency sole ruler appointed for a limited period by the Roman Republic, normally when it was at war (which is usually was in the early days) and things were going badly. The standard practice was to have two heads of government, the consuls, elected on a yearly basis with each having the right to veto the other. In an emergency that had to be laid aside.
Adelfa, dictators dictate, decision made. Facilitators engage to find a consensus decision. They're polar opposites. Mick
